description.narrative: Capacities strengthened in building civic resilience and institutional safeguards for communities to prevent violent extremism through acceptance and effective governance of diversity.

participating-org.narrative: United Nations Counter-Terrorism Centre, Counter-Terrorism Implementation Task Force

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

provider-org.narrative: United Nations Counter-Terrorism Centre, Counter-Terrorism Implementation Task Force
United Nations Counter-Terrorism Centre, Counter-Terrorism Implementation Task Force

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 3.1.1 Global UNDP corporate technical PVE M&E advisory capacity exists (y/n). 3.1.2 Programme and partner mapping exists (y/n). 3.1.3. # private sector entities engaged in UNDP PVE initiatives. 3.1.4 % country or regional PVE project documents referencing findings of “COVID-19/risks” assessments and/or guidance based on assessment findings. 3.2.1 # partner (non-UNDP) entities engaged in production of PVE knowledge materials.* 3.2.2. # individual users who post material (doc, qs, answers, comments) on PVE digital platform. (disaggregated by gender). 3.2.3 # registered members of network of PVE policy makers, researchers, activists including women activists, academics and practitioners. 3.2.4 # action plans that reference core international human rights/ gender rights instruments. 3.2.5 Practitioner-focused guidance on hate speech disseminated (y/n). 3.2.6 # UN Country Team entities participating in UN CT Global Compact Working Group meetings. 3.2.7. Common Principles on PVE M&E exist (y/n). 3.3.1 % STRIVE countries meeting or exceeding annual performance targets. 3.3.2 # countries receiving direct technical assistance to design and implement return and reintegration programmes for foreign terrorist fighters, including a focus on women. 3.3.3 # countries receiving direct technical assistance and/or access to learning opportunities on at least one of: psychosocial support, MEL, conflict analysis, and/or risk management. 3.3.4 % UNDP-UNOCT Action Plan items fully or partially implemented.

comment.narrative: In 34 countries, UNDP supports authorities—at both local and national levels—and civil society to understand and address violent extremism conducive to terrorism through integrated programming that brings together a number of UNDP signature solutions—e.g. livelihoods, governance and the rule of law, conflict prevention and peacebuilding; gender equality. PVE projects also supports implementation of PVE National Action Plans (NAPs), which are recommended in the Secretary General’s PVE Plan of Action, and included in the UNDP Strategic Plan. UNDP PVE-specific project contents are tailored to local needs, usually implemented in cooperation or coordination with 1-4 other UN agencies (UNODC, OHCHR, UNESCO and UN Women) and typically integrate a number of initiatives including institutional support, research, conflict prevention and peacebuilding, conflict sensitivity, access to justice and rule of law, employment creation, hate speech, women and/or youth peace and security.evntion of components nstitutional support.

3.1.1: Global UNDP corporate technical PVE M&E advisory capacity exists. 3.1.2: Programme and partner mapping exists. 3.1.3: 4 private sector entities engaged in CPPRI/ PVE initiatives. 3.1.4: 50% country or regional PVE project documents referencing findings of “COVID-19/risks” assessments and/or guidance based on assessment findings. 3.2.1: 20 partner (non-UNDP) entities engaged in production of CPRI PVE knowledge materials. 3.2.2: 25 individual users who post material (documents, questions, answers, comments) on PVE digital platform. (disaggregated by gender). 3.2.2.1: 800 participants in PVE COP sessions (total). 3.2.3: 80 registered members of network of PVE policy makers, researchers, activists including women activists, academics and practitioners. 3.2.3.1: 60% members of registered network members who agree that they can access the knowledge resources (policy, research, expertise) they need to contribute to gender-responsive policy formulation and practice. 3.2.4: 60% action plans that reference core international human rights/ gender righ Practitioner-focused guidance on hate speech disseminated (y/n). 3.2.5 Practitioner-focused guidance on hate speech disseminated (y/n). 3.2.6: 4 UN Country Team entities participating in UN CT Global Compact Working Group meetings. 3.2.7: Guidelines for PVE impact assessment, M&E exist. 3.3.1: 6% performance targets met or exceeded in STRIVE countries.* 3.3.2: 3 countries receive direct technical assistance to design and implement return and reintegration programmes for foreign terrorist fighters, including a focus on women. 3.3.2.1: 2 countries receiving catalytic seed funding for design and implementation of return and reintegration programmes for foreign terrorist fighters. 3.3.3: 15 countries receiving direct technical assistance and/or access to learning opportunities on at least one of: psychosocial support, MEL, conflict analysis, and/or risk management. 3.3.4: 50% UNDP-UNOCT Action Plan items fully or partially implemented.

3.1.1: Global UNDP corporate technical PVE M&E advisory capacity in place. 3.1.2: Partner mapping completed; Programme mappings completed on MHPSS, M&E and hate speech. 3.1.3: Three private sector entities engaged in CPPRI/PVE initiatives (SecDev, Quilt.AI, Pattrn.AI). 3.1.4: 25% of country PVE project documents referencing findings of COVD-19 risk assessments. 3.2.1: 31 partner (non-UNDP) entities engaged in production of CPRI PVE knowledge materials. 3.2.2: Knowledge dissemination structures improved: PVE Dashboard roll-out initiated, SparkBlue Dashboard developed; SharePoint PVE site. 3.2.3: 104 active members of Sparkblue Dashboard; Av. 145 visitors per week of SharePoint PVE site (av.145 visitors per week); 3.2.3.1: Survey rated overall relevance of PVE CoP av. 4.8 points out of 5 (highly relevant). 3.2.3.2: 1255 PVE Community of Practice participants (in 29 events). 3.2.5: Policy brief and guidance note on the utilization of online data for PVE developed. 3.2.6: Two UN Country Teams participating in UN CT Global Compact Working Group (Iraq, Tunisia). 3.3.1: 45.5% performance targets met or exceeded in STRIVE countries. 3.3.2: 5 COs receive direct technical assistance on return and reintegration programmes for foreign terrorist fighters: Tajikistan, Iraq, Maldives, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan. 3.3.2.1: Agreement signed for funding of return and reintegration efforts in 3 countries (Kazakhstan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan). 3.3.3 - part 1 (M&E): 11 COs and 3 Regional Hubs (BRH, IRH, ARH) receive technical assistance on M&E (MEL) for PVE: Iraq, Trinidad and Tobago, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, Philippines, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Serbia. 3.3.3 - part 2 (hate speech): 10 COs receive technical support to increase reach of digital campaigns to address hate speech and misinformation (Thailand, Chile, Venezuela, Kenya, Iraq, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Zimbabwe, Panama). 3.3.3 - part 3 (hate speech and gender): 3 COs receive direct technical assistance on hate speech programme development, including on gender-responsiveness: Kyrgyzstan, Montenegro, Sri Lanka. 3.3.3 - part 4 (gender): 3 COs and 1 RO receive direct technical assistance on PVE programme development, including on gender- responsiveness: Iraq, Mozambique, Comoros, RBAS. 3.3.4: 66% UNDP-UNOCT Action Plan items fully or partially implemented.
Additional results for knowledge development and country support:
(3.1): Development of (with BPPS/Governance) Research report, policy brief, and programming guide on the Role of Parliaments in Addressing Hate Speech (4 COs and 25 external partners engaged). (3.3): CO PVE M&E capacity assessment conducted. (3.3) Innovative UN inter-agency arrangement for coherent UN support on return and reintegration for foreign terrorist fighters (‘Global Framework’) developed and implementation initiated, with UNDP participation. (3.1): Global consultations on integrating MHPSS in peacebuilding conducted. (3.1): Lessons learned report on UNDP behavioural insights experiments applied to PVE activities in 3 COs developed. (3.1): Development of (with RBA) Research Report on Violent Extremism in Sub-Saharan Africa (10 COs, 7+ external partners, and 5 member states and regional entities engaged). (3.3): Agreement with Beyond Conflict to provide 5 COs (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan) with technical support on integrating MHPSS in PVE activities finalized. (3.3): 5 Country Offices receive support on MHPSS.

PVE global stocktaking exercise conducted. PVE knowledge materials developed. Global Framework to support provision of return and reintegration assistance development initiated, with UNDP support. 10 PVE practitioner knowledge events held. 3 UNDP Country Offices receive technical assistance on MEL. Human rights measurement initiative initiated. MHPSS project mapping conducted. Policy brief on climate security produced and disseminated. STRIVE project implementation commenced in 4 countries.

Guidance Note for practitioners on COVID-19 risks developed and disseminated. Global Framework developed initiated, with UNDP participation. Hate speech project mapping conducted. 14 Practitioner knowledge exchange events held. 9 Country Offices receive direct technical assistance on MEL: Iraq, Trinidad and Tobago, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia, Philippines, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Pakistan). Concept Note on “Measuring the Human Rights Impact of Efforts Aimed at PVE produced. MHPSS project mapping initiated. STRIVE project implementation commenced in 3 countries (Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Turkmenistan).
